institute: Institute of Informatics and Artificial Intelligence
dean: Dean of FAI TBU in Zlín
homeWelcome: Welcome to the Robogames information system!
homeP1: This page serves as an information system for managing and organizing the Robogames competition. It is intended for participant registration, team management, categories, and organizing the competition process.
homeP2: The main website with information for the public, competition rules, news and program can be found at:
homeP3: Robogames is a competition organized by the Faculty of Applied Informatics of Tomas Bata University in Zlín since 2017. The competition takes place on the Faculty of Applied Informatics campus and is intended for students of secondary and higher schools, primary school pupils, members of robotics clubs, and other enthusiasts from the general public.
howToRegisterDesc: Follow these simple steps to sign up for the competition
guideStep1Desc: Register in the system or log in if you already have an account.
guideStep2Desc: Create a new team or get invited to an existing one.
guideStep3Desc: In the My Team section, click the button to register for the competition.
guideStep4Desc: On the registration page, select a specific competition year and confirm.
guideStep5Desc: Add robots to your registration and choose their disciplines.
readyToStartDesc: Register today and show the world what your robots can do!

ageCatP1: Based on date of birth (entered in the application), competitors are divided into the following categories:
partsP: Besides LEGO kits, Robogames aims to support robots built from anything. We want to motivate all robotics enthusiasts and students to participate regardless of whether they can afford the “official” LEGO kits. We believe success should be determined primarily by talent, effort, and a bit of luck. We understand concerns of “official” kit users that they may be disadvantaged (e.g., weaker motors or batteries). However, they can be inspired at our competition and attach stronger (“unofficial”) components to their official kits.
teamsP: In all competitions, a multi-member team may compete with a single robot. In case of victory, the team receives only one physical prize.
regP: You may register one robot per team for each discipline. If a team participates in multiple disciplines, a different robot can be used for each discipline.
scheduleP1: Before the competition starts, a starting schedule will be prepared that competitors must follow. Failure to comply may result in a penalty up to disqualification.
scheduleP2: On the referee’s call, the competitor must perform their run. Delays are allowed only for robot repairs or battery replacement.
scheduleP3: If the competitor refuses to compete when asked by the organizers, they will not be allowed to perform the discipline.
sumoP: The goal is a duel of two robots trying to push the opponent out of the ring.
max20cm: Maximum robot dimensions: footprint max 20×20 cm, height unlimited
sumoRuleP1: The goal is a duel of two robots trying to push the opponent out of the ring.
sumoRuleP2: Robots may have unlimited height, but their footprint must be at most 20×20 cm. Compliance is checked by inserting the robot into a frame with an inner size of 20×20 cm. The robot must pass through the frame.
sumoRuleP3: The robot may weigh at most 1 kg. The weight limit is checked before entering the ring and also after battery replacement.
sumoRuleP4: After the match starts, the robot may increase its dimensions, e.g., by deploying decoys.
sumoRuleP5: The robot may split into several separate parts or robots after the start. If any part ends up outside the ring, the robot loses.
sumoRuleP6: The robot must not use any techniques to change adhesion to the ring surface, whether mechanical or chemical.
sumoRuleP7: The robot must not soil the ring surface. It must not release any substances (glues, oils, degreasers, smoke, fog, etc.).
sumoRuleP8: The robot may only push the opponent. Destructive or disabling techniques are forbidden (e.g., shooting, hammer blows, flames, electric shocks, nets, or materials that tangle on wheel shafts, etc.).
sumoRuleP9: The sumo ring has a diameter of 154 cm. It is made of black laminated chipboard 1 cm thick, mounted on 4 cm legs. The ring has a 5 cm white border. Starting lines are brown, 2 cm wide, 20 cm apart—see dimensions in Fig. 1.
sumoRuleP10: The ring is assembled from two halves, so there is a joint along the center that is not perfectly smooth.
sumoRuleP11: A match lasts a maximum of 9 minutes of active time and consists of up to three valid rounds, so one round is 3 minutes. The round winner gets 1 point and the match ends when one robot gets 2 points.
sumoRuleP12: The match starts with robots placed on designated marks facing away. On the referee’s signal, competitors start them. For the first 5 seconds, the robot must not move, but may signal activity (e.g., light or sound). Within 5 seconds after the start, competitors must step back at least 150 cm. If a robot moves within the first five seconds, it may be penalized or disqualified.
sumoRuleP13: If a robot crosses onto the other half of the ring for the first time, it must turn at least 90 ° from the starting position.
sumoRuleP14: A robot loses a round when any part of it touches the base beneath the ring.
sumoRuleP15: If after 3 minutes in the decisive third round both robots have the same number of points, the referee may order overtime or award the winning point for greater activity.
sumoRuleP16: If robots are locked together and/or their movement does not promise change for more than 5 seconds, the referee may order a new round.
sumoRuleP17: If a robot stops and stands still for more than 5 seconds, its opponent gets 1 point and the round ends.
sumoRuleP18: The robot moves autonomously only; no communication with the robot is allowed during a round.
sumoRuleP19: Depending on the number of competitors, they are divided into groups with round-robin matches or into a single group competing in the same way.
sumoRuleP20: The winner of the entire competition is the one who gains the most points.
miniP: A Robosumo variant that shares its rules with this version.
followP: The winner is the robot that completes the track—black line on white background—the fastest. The track includes curves, right (sharp) corners, and intersections; the robot must follow the line from start to finish as precisely as possible.
followP1: robots with a single line sensor (formerly "LEGO")
max25cm: Maximum robot dimensions: footprint max 25×25 cm, height unlimited
followRuleP1: The track is made of white plastic foil (used for advertising banners) sized 280×200 cm with a 15 mm wide black line. The smallest curve radius is 10 cm; the minimum spacing of parallel lines (“grid”) is 20 cm.
followRuleP2: The robot must follow the line from start to finish.
followRuleP3: If the robot leaves the line, finds it again, and does not shorten the route, the run is valid.
followRuleP4: If the robot leaves the line, finds it again, and shortens the route, the referee declares the run invalid.
followRuleP5: Until the 3-minute limit expires, the robot may be placed back at the start to attempt another run. The result is the shortest time.
followRuleP6: If the robot never reaches the finish within the time limit, the referee records only the number of checkpoints passed and the maximum attempt time.
followRuleP7: Robots that do not finish are penalized a fixed value (1 minute) for each checkpoint not passed; the penalty is added to the attempt.
followRuleP8: The robot moves autonomously only; during the run, any communication with the robot is forbidden.
followRuleP9: The competitor performs the “live” competition run only once; repeated attempts are not allowed.
followRuleP10: Unless the registration form states otherwise, robots must perform their attempt on both track types (see below).
lego: LEGO - The robot is equipped with only one optical sensor
mcu: MCU - The robot may be equipped with multiple sensors
track: Track examples (the displayed pattern may not be used):
cleanerP1: The robot moves on an area sized 140×100 cm.
cleanerP2: The area is made of a white Sololak board bordered with 30 mm black electrical tape.
cleanerP3: Six Lego® Duplo blocks are placed on the area.
cleanerP4: The robot has three attempts, each three minutes long, to deliver as many blocks as possible to the defined zone.
cleanerP5: The delivery zone is a circular sector with a radius of 30 cm in a corner of the competition area.
cleanerP6: The starting position is diagonally opposite the delivery zone.
cleanerP7: In the target zone there is a box at least 30 cm high, placed at a 45 ° angle to the edges of the area at a distance of 10 cm.
cleanerP8: Blocks are placed randomly and their positions are identical for each competitor.
cleanerP9: The robot has three minutes to collect blocks and deliver them to the defined place. If not all are collected within the limit, one minute is added to the attempt time for each block not delivered.
cleanerP10: The competitor may end the attempt at any time by notifying the referee. The referee records the attempt time and the number of blocks delivered.
cleanerP11: The winner is the robot with the shortest attempt time.
cleanerV1: The robot only delivers blocks to the defined area.
cleanerV1P1: A block counts if, after the attempt ends, at least part of it is inside the defined area.
cleanerV1P2: Blocks delivered and then pushed out again are not counted.
cleanerV2: The robot throws blocks into a box.
cleanerV2P1: In the corner of the target zone, a box is placed instead of the previous container; blocks are thrown into it.
cleanerV2P2: The box dimensions are 210×210×100 mm. The back side is 300 mm high.
cleanerV2P3: A block counts only if, after the attempt, it is inside the box.
